abstract.text: We present studies from the LHCb experiment leading to the measurement of the weak phase φ s .
At first, flavor tagging is established by measuring the B 0 s oscillation frequency ∆m s .
Then, flavor tagging is used to perform a measurement of the well known CKM angle sin 2β in B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S , before we constrain φ s through an amplitude analysis of B 0 s → J/ψ φ decays.
These studies use about 35 pb −1 of data taken in 2010.
In addition, we present the measurement of B(B + → J/ψ π + )/B(B + → J/ψ K + ) and the first observation of B 0 s → J/ψ f 2 (1525).

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
Decays of neutral B mesons provide a unique laboratory to study CP violation originating from a weak phase in the CKM matrix.
The relative phase between two amplitudes, direct decay and decay after mixing, gives rise to time-dependent CP violation.
The decay B 0 s → J/ψ φ is considered the golden mode for measuring this type of CP violation in the B 0 s system.
In the Standard Model, the CP violating phase in this decay is predicted to be φ s ≈ −2β s , where
Indirect measurements show 2β s is small, 2β s = (0.0363 ± 0.0017) rad [1].
But new contributions to B 0 s -B 0 s mixing may alter the expected value of φ s [2,3].
Previous constraints on φ s at the 0.5 rad level have been reported by the Tevatron experiments CDF [4] and D0 [5].
The precise determination of φ s is one of the key goals of the LHCb experiment [6].
In this letter we present a series of measurements leading the way to a measurement of φ s .
CONSTRAINTS ON φ s
We first present [7] a measurement of the mixing frequency ∆m s of the B 0 s system, using about 1350 B 0 s signal candidates reconstructed in 36 pb −1 collected in 2010 through their decays
This measurement demonstrates that the achieved decay time resolution (44 fs in D − s π, 36 fs in D − s 3π) is sufficient to resolve the fast oscillations in B 0 s mixing.
It also establishes the flavor tagging algorithms required to identify the B 0 s flavor at production time.
The effective tagging efficiency is ε eff = 3.8±2.1(stat)%.
Figure 1 shows the result of an amplitude scan, converging to ∆m s = 17.63 ± 0.11(stat) ± 0.04(syst) ps −1 , which is compatible with the Tevatron measurements and of similar precision.
We then [8] make use of the flavor tagging algorithms to repeat the measurement of the CKM angle sin 2β , which was determined by the B factories to amazing precision: sin 2β = 0.673 ± 0.023 [9].
In 35 pb −1 we find about 280 tagged B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S decays, considered the golden channel for this measurement.
A maximum likelihood fit to the decay time distribution and the B 0 invariant mass, simultaneously fitting tagged and untagged samples, reports sin 2β S = 0.53 +0.28 −0.29 (stat) ± 0.05(syst).
The systematic uncertainty is dominated by that on the flavor tagging.
Although not yet competitive with the result of the B-factories a very precise measurement will be possible with the data that LHCb will collect over the coming few years.

Figure 1 shows the time dependent raw asymmetry of B 0 and B 0 decaying into J/ψ K 0 S , the amplitude of which is proportional to S. Finally, we perform [10] an untagged angular analysis of B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 and B 0 s → J/ψ φ decays.
This gives access to the decay amplitudes for both final states, as well as the lifetime and lifetime difference ∆Γ s for B 0 s → J/ψ φ .
Due to the forward geometry of the LHCb detector, the reconstruction efficiency for these decays is a non-trivial function 1    of the fits.
In the limit of infinite statistics and perfectly calibrated tagging performance and proper time resolution we expect A to be zero for all m s values but the true one.
For the fit with the true m s value the amplitude is expected to be exactly one.
Figure 8 shows (A, A ) as a function of m s .
We find A = 1.41 ± 0.26 for m s = 17.63 ps 1 , which is 1.6 away from the expected value of 1.
This indicates that either our proper time resolution or tagging performance estimate is slightly too pessimistic or that we observe a statistical fluctuation.
The separation of A = 1.41 and A = 0 is 5.4 (statistical uncertainties only).
This number gives the separation between the hypothesis of a mixing frequency of m s = 17.63 ps 1 and no mixing.
of the decay angles.
Then we add [11] the flavor tagging information to the measurement.
In the 36 pb −1 of 2010 we find approximately 760 B 0 s → J/ψ φ events.
We extract constraints on φ s through a maximum likelihood fit to the decay time distribution, the B 0 s invariant mass, and three decay angles.
The data sample is too small to allow for meaningful point estimates.
Instead we perform a Feldman-Cousins analysis which gives contours in the ∆Γ s − φ s plane ( Figure 2) that have frequentist coverage.
We observe a deviation from the Standard Model of 1.2σ , and constrain φ s ∈ [−2.7, −0.5] rad at the 68.3% confidence level.
ANALYSIS OF

Following our recent first observation of the B 0 s → J/ψ f 0 decay [12], we update [13] the analysis of the B 0 s → J/ψ ππ final state with a larger dataset of 162 pb −1 , coming mostly from the first period of the 2011 run.
We also show that the f 0 resonance is consistent with being purely S-wave, making J/ψ f 0 a pure CP odd eigenstate.
This will allow for a measurement of φ s in B 0 s → J/ψ f 0 decays without the need of an amplitude analysis.
We measure the ratio of rates in a ±90 MeV/c 2 mass window around the f 0 (980), R
, to be R f 0 effective = (21.7 ± 1.1(stat) ± 0.7(syst))%.
We extend our analysis to the B 0 s → J/ψ K + K − final state.
In the K + K − invariant mass spectrum we for the first time observe, in addition to the φ (1020) component, a structure that we identify as the spin-2 f 2 (1525).
An angular analysis confirms, that the data are consistent with the spin-2, and inconsistent with the spin-0 hypothesis.
The B 0 s → J/ψ f 2 mode can also be used to measure φ s , although here a transversity analysis would be required as in J/ψ φ .
It is also criteria, and (right) tight kaon ID criteria.
The results of the fits are shown in Fig. 14.
The resulting mass from the fit is 1525±4 MeV and there are 296±26 events.
If we allow the width to float we find a consistent value of 90 +16 14 MeV.
As we have not taken into account possible interferences between the f 0 2 (1525) and other J/ K + K final states we do not quote measured values of the mass and width at this time.
The f 0 2 (1525) is a G-parity even state and its spin has been measured as two [12].

Figure 3 shows both the J/ψ K + K − and the K + K − invariant mass spectra for this first observation.

We also analyze [14] the B + → J/ψ π + and B + → J/ψ K + decay channels, of which the latter plays an important role in the calibration of the flavor tagging algorithms.
In 37 pb −1 we measure the ratio of their branching fractions to be B(B + → J/ψ π + )/B(B + → J/ψ K + ) = (3.94±0.39(stat)±0.17(syst))×10 −2 .
This result has a precision comparable to the present world average [15], but is lower by 2.2σ .
